history.content:
The basic background in linear algebra for students in our neck of the woods is that provided by EE16A and EE16B together. This is why all students are strongly encouraged to take these courses. In those courses, you will also learn why these concepts are important. So for concrete advice, students who for whatever reason are taking Math 54 (despite our explicit guidance to the contrary), are encouraged to follow along in EE16A and EE16B to understand where linear algebraic concepts are coming from and why they are important. 

EE16AB are just the baby basics however (and even they together go beyond Math 54). To get a more solid background, you are encouraged to take the next level of course at the intro upper-div level--- for example, courses like Math 110 (for the complementary more abstract perspective, as well as the treatment of Jordan forms) and EECS127 (for deepening the connections between linear algebra and optimization, as well as vector calculus). If you have to pick just one, that course would be EECS127. 

For most folks, the combination of 16A, 16B, and 127 should carry you pretty far. Including in advanced upper division courses like 189.

Currently a student taking Math 54. I realize it's these concepts are very fundamental for a lot of upper divs and especially for ML stuff. However, I've realized most of 54 is very abstract and theoretical and I can't really get myself to enjoy the material. 

What topics within linear algebra (perhaps specifically in the 54 syllabus) are the most important for applications? I would really like some inspiration in order to better concentrate my efforts in this class.
history.subject: What's considered a 'good background in linear algebra'?
